div.l: And as ful of hokir͗e and of bismare
Hir thought that a ladi shuld hir spare
What for hir kinrede ⁊and hir nurtilrye
Þat she had lerned in the nonnerye
A doughter had they betwyx hem two
Of xxᵗⁱ yere wᵗithouten̄ any moo
Sauyng a child that half yer͗e was of age
In cradil it lay and was a ꝓpropir͗e page
Þis wench thik and wele y grow was
Wᵗith camois nose and iyen̄ grey as glas
Wᵗith buttokꝭis brood and brestis round ⁊and hye
But right feir was hir here I nyl not lye
Þe p̉erson̄ of the tovn̄ for she was so feyr͗e
In purpos was to make hir his heire
Both of his catel and of his mesuage
⁊And straunge he made it of hir mariage
His purpose was to bestow hir hye
Into sum wurthi blood of Auncestrye
For holichurch good must be dispendid A Squibb for pro /ude prelates or / covetous churchmēn
On holi churchis blood that is descendid
Therefore he wil his holi blood honour͗e
Þough that he shuld holi church devour͗e
¶Greet socoıı̄ur haþ this Milner out of dout
Wᵗith whete and malt al the lond about
And nameli ther was a grete College
Men̄ clepen the Scoler halle of Cambrigge
Ther was her whete and her malt yground
And on a day it happend in a Stounde
Seke lay the manciple on a maladye
Men went wisly that he shuld dye
For which this Milner stale boþ mele ⁊and corn̄
An hundird times more þan he did beforn̄
For though beforn̄ he stale but curteisly
Now he was a thefe Outragiously
For which the wardeyn̄ chid ⁊and made fare
But therof sette not the Milner͗e a Tare
